--- title: "Class 10: Haloween mini project" author: "Michael Romero A18135877" format: html toc: true --- As it is nearly Halloween and the half way point in the quarter let's do a mini project to help us figure out the best candy! Our come from the 538 website and is available as a CSV file: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy_file <- read.csv("candy-data.txt") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy = read.csv("candy-data.txt", row.names=1) head(candy) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` chocolate fruity caramel peanutyalmondy nougat crispedricewafer 100 Grand 1 0 1 0 0 1 3 Musketeers 1 0 0 0 1 0 One dime 0 0 0 0 0 0 One quarter 0 0 0 0 0 0 Air Heads 0 1 0 0 0 0 Almond Joy 1 0 0 1 0 0 hard bar pluribus sugarpercent pricepercent winpercent 100 Grand 0 1 0 0.732 0.860 66.97173 3 Musketeers 0 1 0 0.604 0.511 67.60294 One dime 0 0 0 0.011 0.116 32.26109 One quarter 0 0 0 0.011 0.511 46.11650 Air Heads 0 0 0 0.906 0.511 52.34146 Almond Joy 0 1 0 0.465 0.767 50.34755 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} flextable::flextable(head(candy,10)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: The functions dim(), nrow(), table() and sum() may be useful for answering the first 2 questions. > Q1. How many different candy types are in this dataset? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} nrow(candy) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 85 ``` ::: ::: > Q2. How many fruity candy types are in the dataset? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.5 ✔ forcats 1.0.1 ✔ stringr 1.5.2 ✔ ggplot2 4.0.0 ✔ tibble 3.3.0 ✔ lubridate 1.9.4 ✔ tidyr 1.3.1 ✔ purrr 1.1.0 ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ℹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} candy |> ncol() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 12 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) candy %>% nrow() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 85 ``` ::: ::: Count how many candy are fruity? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sum(candy$fruity) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 38 ``` ::: ::: My facorite winpercent ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy["Almond Joy",]$winpercent ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 50.34755 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(dplyr) candy |> filter(rownames(candy)=="Almond Joy") |> select(winpercent) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` winpercent Almond Joy 50.34755 ``` ::: ::: > Q3. What is your favorite candy in the dataset and what is it’s winpercent value? > Q4. What is the winpercent value for “Kit Kat”? > Q5. What is the winpercent value for “Tootsie Roll Snack Bars”? ##Quick overview of the dataset ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} skimr::skim(candy) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} Table: Data summary | | | |:------------------------|:-----| |Name |candy | |Number of rows |85 | |Number of columns |12 | |_______________________ | | |Column type frequency: | | |numeric |12 | |________________________ | | |Group variables |None | **Variable type: numeric** |skim_variable | n_missing| complete_rate| mean| sd| p0| p25| p50| p75| p100|hist | |:----------------|---------:|-------------:|-----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|:-----| |chocolate | 0| 1| 0.44| 0.50| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▆ | |fruity | 0| 1| 0.45| 0.50| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▆ | |caramel | 0| 1| 0.16| 0.37| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▂ | |peanutyalmondy | 0| 1| 0.16| 0.37| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▂ | |nougat | 0| 1| 0.08| 0.28| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▁ | |crispedricewafer | 0| 1| 0.08| 0.28| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▁ | |hard | 0| 1| 0.18| 0.38| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▂ | |bar | 0| 1| 0.25| 0.43| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▂ | |pluribus | 0| 1| 0.52| 0.50| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00| 1.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▇ | |sugarpercent | 0| 1| 0.48| 0.28| 0.01| 0.22| 0.47| 0.73| 0.99|▇▇▇▇▆ | |pricepercent | 0| 1| 0.47| 0.29| 0.01| 0.26| 0.47| 0.65| 0.98|▇▇▇▇▆ | |winpercent | 0| 1| 50.32| 14.71| 22.45| 39.14| 47.83| 59.86| 84.18|▃▇▆▅▂ | ::: ::: >Q6. The winpercent is on a 0-100 scale the rest are 0-1 scale. >Q7. That the candy does not contain chocolate >Q8. Plot a histogram of winpercent values ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(candy, aes(x=winpercent)) + geom_histogram() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lab-10--Haloween-Candy_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: >Q9. Is the distribution of winpercent values symmetrical? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(candy) + aes(winpercent) + geom_density() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lab-10--Haloween-Candy_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: The peak is before 50 and thus is not symmetrical. >Q10. Is the center of the distribution above or below 50%? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mean(candy$winpercent) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 50.31676 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(candy$winpercent) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Max. 22.45 39.14 47.83 50.32 59.86 84.18 ``` ::: ::: The center of distribution is below 50 since the median is at 47.83% win percent. >Q11. On average is chocolate candy higher or lower ranked than fruit candy? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} #1. Find all chocolte candy in the dataset #2. Find their winpercent values #3. Calculate the mean of these values #4-6. Do the same for fruity candy #7. Compare mean winpercents of chocolate vs fruity #8. Pick the highest as winner choc.inds <- candy$chocolate==1 choc.win <- candy[choc.inds,]$winpercent choc.mean <- mean(choc.win) choc.mean ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 60.92153 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mean(candy[candy$chocolate==1,]$winpercent) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 60.92153 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fruit.ind <- candy$fruity==1 fruit.win <- candy[fruit.ind,]$winpercent fruit.mean <- mean(fruit.win) fruit.mean ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 44.11974 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy |> filter(chocolate==1) |> select(winpercent) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` winpercent 100 Grand 66.97173 3 Musketeers 67.60294 Almond Joy 50.34755 Baby Ruth 56.91455 Charleston Chew 38.97504 Hershey's Kisses 55.37545 Hershey's Krackel 62.28448 Hershey's Milk Chocolate 56.49050 Hershey's Special Dark 59.23612 Junior Mints 57.21925 Kit Kat 76.76860 Peanut butter M&M's 71.46505 M&M's 66.57458 Milk Duds 55.06407 Milky Way 73.09956 Milky Way Midnight 60.80070 Milky Way Simply Caramel 64.35334 Mounds 47.82975 Mr Good Bar 54.52645 Nestle Butterfinger 70.73564 Nestle Crunch 66.47068 Peanut M&Ms 69.48379 Reese's Miniatures 81.86626 Reese's Peanut Butter cup 84.18029 Reese's pieces 73.43499 Reese's stuffed with pieces 72.88790 Rolo 65.71629 Sixlets 34.72200 Nestle Smarties 37.88719 Snickers 76.67378 Snickers Crisper 59.52925 Tootsie Pop 48.98265 Tootsie Roll Juniors 43.06890 Tootsie Roll Midgies 45.73675 Tootsie Roll Snack Bars 49.65350 Twix 81.64291 Whoppers 49.52411 ``` ::: ::: >Q12. Is this difference statistically significant? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} t.test(choc.win, fruit.win) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Welch Two Sample t-test data: choc.win and fruit.win t = 6.2582, df = 68.882, p-value = 2.871e-08 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 11.44563 22.15795 sample estimates: mean of x mean of y 60.92153 44.11974 ``` ::: ::: The difference is significant as p-value < 0.05. >Q13. What are the five least liked candy types in this set? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ord.ind <- order(candy$winpercent) head( candy[ord.ind,], 5 ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` chocolate fruity caramel peanutyalmondy nougat Nik L Nip 0 1 0 0 0 Boston Baked Beans 0 0 0 1 0 Chiclets 0 1 0 0 0 Super Bubble 0 1 0 0 0 Jawbusters 0 1 0 0 0 crispedricewafer hard bar pluribus sugarpercent pricepercent Nik L Nip 0 0 0 1 0.197 0.976 Boston Baked Beans 0 0 0 1 0.313 0.511 Chiclets 0 0 0 1 0.046 0.325 Super Bubble 0 0 0 0 0.162 0.116 Jawbusters 0 1 0 1 0.093 0.511 winpercent Nik L Nip 22.44534 Boston Baked Beans 23.41782 Chiclets 24.52499 Super Bubble 27.30386 Jawbusters 28.12744 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy %>% arrange(ascending=winpercent) %>% head(5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` chocolate fruity caramel peanutyalmondy nougat Nik L Nip 0 1 0 0 0 Boston Baked Beans 0 0 0 1 0 Chiclets 0 1 0 0 0 Super Bubble 0 1 0 0 0 Jawbusters 0 1 0 0 0 crispedricewafer hard bar pluribus sugarpercent pricepercent Nik L Nip 0 0 0 1 0.197 0.976 Boston Baked Beans 0 0 0 1 0.313 0.511 Chiclets 0 0 0 1 0.046 0.325 Super Bubble 0 0 0 0 0.162 0.116 Jawbusters 0 1 0 1 0.093 0.511 winpercent Nik L Nip 22.44534 Boston Baked Beans 23.41782 Chiclets 24.52499 Super Bubble 27.30386 Jawbusters 28.12744 ``` ::: ::: >Q14. What are the top 5 all time favorite candy types out of this set? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy %>% arrange(descending=candy$winpercent) %>% tail(5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` chocolate fruity caramel peanutyalmondy nougat Snickers 1 0 1 1 1 Kit Kat 1 0 0 0 0 Twix 1 0 1 0 0 Reese's Miniatures 1 0 0 1 0 Reese's Peanut Butter cup 1 0 0 1 0 crispedricewafer hard bar pluribus sugarpercent Snickers 0 0 1 0 0.546 Kit Kat 1 0 1 0 0.313 Twix 1 0 1 0 0.546 Reese's Miniatures 0 0 0 0 0.034 Reese's Peanut Butter cup 0 0 0 0 0.720 pricepercent winpercent Snickers 0.651 76.67378 Kit Kat 0.511 76.76860 Twix 0.906 81.64291 Reese's Miniatures 0.279 81.86626 Reese's Peanut Butter cup 0.651 84.18029 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy |> arrange(-winpercent) |> head(5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` chocolate fruity caramel peanutyalmondy nougat Reese's Peanut Butter cup 1 0 0 1 0 Reese's Miniatures 1 0 0 1 0 Twix 1 0 1 0 0 Kit Kat 1 0 0 0 0 Snickers 1 0 1 1 1 crispedricewafer hard bar pluribus sugarpercent Reese's Peanut Butter cup 0 0 0 0 0.720 Reese's Miniatures 0 0 0 0 0.034 Twix 1 0 1 0 0.546 Kit Kat 1 0 1 0 0.313 Snickers 0 0 1 0 0.546 pricepercent winpercent Reese's Peanut Butter cup 0.651 84.18029 Reese's Miniatures 0.279 81.86626 Twix 0.906 81.64291 Kit Kat 0.511 76.76860 Snickers 0.651 76.67378 ``` ::: ::: >Q15. Make a first barplot of candy ranking based on winpercent values. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(candy) + aes(x=winpercent, y=reorder(rownames(candy), winpercent)) + geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lab-10--Haloween-Candy_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Add some color based on the type of candy ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} my_cols=rep("black", nrow(candy)) my_cols[as.logical(candy$chocolate)] = "chocolate" my_cols[as.logical(candy$bar)] = "brown" my_cols[as.logical(candy$fruity)] = "pink" ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(candy) + aes(winpercent, reorder(rownames(candy),winpercent)) + geom_col(fill=my_cols) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lab-10--Haloween-Candy_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ##Winpercent and Pricepercent A plot with both variables/columns winpercent and pricepercent ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggrepel) ggplot(candy) + aes(x=winpercent, y=pricepercent, label=rownames(candy)) + geom_point(col=my_cols) + geom_text_repel(max.overlaps=7) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: ggrepel: 45 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider increasing max.overlaps ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lab-10--Haloween-Candy_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: > Q17. What is the worst ranked chocolate candy? The worst ranked chocolate candy is sixlet. > Q18. What is the best ranked fruity candy? The best ranked fruity candy is starburst. ##Exploring the correlation structure Now that we've explored the dataset a little we'll see how the variables interact with each other. ... the corrplot package to plot a correlation matrix. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(corrplot) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` corrplot 0.95 loaded ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cij <- cor(candy) corrplot(cij) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lab-10--Haloween-Candy_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Principal Component Analysis The function to use is called `prcomp()` with an optional `scale=T/F` argument. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pca <- prcomp(candy, scale=TRUE) summary(pca) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Importance of components: PC1 PC2 PC3 PC4 PC5 PC6 PC7 Standard deviation 2.0788 1.1378 1.1092 1.07533 0.9518 0.81923 0.81530 Proportion of Variance 0.3601 0.1079 0.1025 0.09636 0.0755 0.05593 0.05539 Cumulative Proportion 0.3601 0.4680 0.5705 0.66688 0.7424 0.79830 0.85369 PC8 PC9 PC10 PC11 PC12 Standard deviation 0.74530 0.67824 0.62349 0.43974 0.39760 Proportion of Variance 0.04629 0.03833 0.03239 0.01611 0.01317 Cumulative Proportion 0.89998 0.93832 0.97071 0.98683 1.00000 ``` ::: ::: Our main PCA result figure ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(pca$x) + aes(PC1, PC2, label=rownames(pca$x)) + geom_point(col=my_cols) + geom_text_repel(col=my_cols) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: ggrepel: 21 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider increasing max.overlaps ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lab-10--Haloween-Candy_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: We should also examine the variable "loadings" or contributions of the original variables to the new PCs ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(pca$rotation) + aes(PC1, rownames(pca$rotation)) + geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lab-10--Haloween-Candy_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
